metadata.case_name: Trustee of Public Trust, Amritsar v. Amritsar Improvement Trust & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant claims to be the trustee of a Public Trust created for the management of certain properties situated in Amritsar, including a dharamshala bearing Municipal No. 2320/1, 884/9.

By resolution dated March 21, 1957, Amritsar Improvement Trust decided to acquire a portion of the appellant's property for widening a road under a development scheme framed under s. 3 of the Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951.

Scheme framed under s. 3, published under s. 4 specifying affected properties and objection period, objections considered under s. 5, sanctioned and published under s. 5(3), deemed duly framed and sanctioned.
Appellant filed suit for declaration that acquisition proceedings were illegal and ultra vires, and for permanent injunction; suit withdrawn by Consent Memo.
Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court challenging validity of Improvement Trust's action and seeking quashing of acquisition proceedings; dismissed summarily on April 20, 1961.
Appellant's petition for certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) dismissed by Punjab High Court.
Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court to appeal against High Court judgment.
Under s. 93 of Government of India Act, 1935, Governor of Punjab enacted Punjab Damaged Areas Act, 1947 (Punj. Act 11 of 1947); s. 3 enabled declaration of damaged areas by notification.
Notification issued in April 1948 under s. 3 of 1947 Act declaring area (including appellant's property) as damaged area.
1947 Act temporary; rule under s. 93 ended August 15, 1947; would lapse August 15, 1949 per s. 93(4); continued till then by India Provisional Constitution Order, 1947 cl. 6.

East Punjab Damaged Areas Act, 1949 enacted to fill gap post-1947 Act expiry; s. 3 brought into force April 1949; ss. 4-21 not brought into force before August 15, 1949; no notification under s. 1(3) found.

legal_issues.text: Proper construction of the definition of 'damaged area' in s. 2(d) of the Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951, specifically whether notification under Punjab Damaged Areas Act, 1947 is included via the 1949 Act.
Whether s. 5(4) of the 1951 Act provides conclusive evidence of scheme validity precluding challenge to jurisdiction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Acquisition illegal as area not 'damaged area' under s. 2(d) of 1951 Act; notification was under 1947 Act, not 1949 Act; no repeal/re-enactment of 1947 by 1949 to deem 1948 notification under 1949 via Punjab General Clauses Act s. 22.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 2(d) Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951; Punjab Damaged Areas Act, 1947; East Punjab Damaged Areas Act, 1949; Punjab General Clauses Act s. 22

respondent_arguments.text: 1949 Act repealed and re-enacted 1947 Act; by Punjab General Clauses Act s. 22, 1948 notification under 1947 deemed issued under 1949; thus included in s. 2(d) of 1951 Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Punjab General Clauses Act s. 22; s. 2(d) 1951 Act

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant precluded from challenging scheme by s. 5(4) of 1951 Act, which provides conclusive evidence of due framing and sanction upon publication under s. 5(3).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 5(4) Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951

court_reasoning.text: No repeal of 1947 Act by 1949 Act, express or implied; 1947 temporary and expired; 1949 reproduces but does not repeal; no inconsistency for implied repeal; s. 22 Punjab General Clauses Act inapplicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Implied repeals not favoured, especially identical parallel enactments.

court_reasoning.text: s. 2(d) of 1951 Act refers only to notifications under s. 3 of 1949 Act, not 1947 Act even if deemed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Normal construction limits to actual notifications under 1949.

court_reasoning.text: s. 5(4) conclusive only as to formalities under ss. 3,4,5; does not cover total lack of jurisdiction if area not 'damaged area' per s. 2(d).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jurisdictional defect not cured by conclusive evidence clause.

holdings.text: Area not 'damaged area' under s. 2(d) of 1951 Act as notification under 1947 not included; Improvement Trust lacked power to frame scheme under s. 3.
s. 5(4) does not preclude challenge where complete lack of jurisdiction due to area not being damaged area.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Punjab v. Mohar Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Temporary enactments can be repealed and re-enacted to attract s. 22 Punjab General Clauses Act.

outcome.summary: Appeal succeeds; proceedings for acquisition of appellant's property under Punjab Development of Damaged Areas Act, 1951 quashed as area not 'damaged area' under s. 2(d).

key_quotes.text: The point arising for decision in this appeal by special leave is a very short one and relates to the proper construction of the definition of damaged area in s. 2(d) of the Punjab Development and Damaged Areas Act, 1951.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is a maxim of the law that implied repeals are not to be favoured, and where two statutes are entirely affirmative and identical no question of inconsistency could arise.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The foundation of the jurisdiction of the Improvement Trust to frame a scheme... depends upon the scheme relating to a damaged area and if... the property is within an area which does not fall within the definition of a damaged area under s. 2(d) of the Act, it follows that there was total lack of jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why s. 5(4) does not bar challenge.
